title: Vile rapists among North East criminals jailed in April 2025
body_text:
Vile rapists among North East criminals jailed in April 2025 - full list of offenders locked up
A number of people were handed prison sentences of more than 10 years for rape, sexual offences and other crimes - here are their faces
Criminals who carried out despicable sex offences were among those who were locked up in April.
A number of North East people were given jail terms of more than a decade for offences including rape, sexual assault, sexual activity with a child and sexual abuse. Courts heard details of the sick crimes as the perpetrators were sentenced.
Among them was Jeffrey Rose, who escaped justice for almost half a century but was put behind bars thanks to the victim's bravery. Rose, now 75, targeted his victim in the late 1970s. However, she did not report what had happened to her until 2020.
He denied the allegations but following a trial was found guilty of 20 offences including rape, attempted rape and indecent assault. Rose was jailed for 17 years.
Elsewhere, a rapist was jailed after he attacked a woman with a crossbow and threatened to kill her. Michael Holmes raped and assaulted the woman and even aimed a crossbow at her. However, after pulling the trigger, the crossbow malfunctioned and the arrow missed the woman.
Keep up to date with all the latest court news from the North East with our free newsletter
Holmes was charged with several offences, including two counts of rape, one count of attempted rape, sexual assault, causing grievous bodily harm with intent, and attempting to cause grievous bodily harm. He denied the offences but was found guilty following a trial and was sentenced to 16 years behind bars.
Below we have outlined further details of these cases as well as others covered by ChronicleLive in April 2025 where the defendants received a prison sentence. As well as sex offences, crimes included robbery, assault, theft, making threats and drug-related offences.
Sam Grant
A pub quiz runner up left the winner needing hospital treatment after attacking him after the event.
The victim had gone to a quiz at the Anson pub, on Station Road, Wallsend. Afterwards, he was talking to the quiz host next to the exit when Sam Grant, who had come second to him, came between them.
There was an incident in which the victim was slapped and punched in the face. The victim went to hospital and was left with a black eye and a cut to the top of his eye which required stitches. He also had possible broken ribs and a cut to his arm.
Grant 30, of Northumberland Street, Wallsend, then got involved in further violence in August last year on Grainger Street, Newcastle. He pleaded guilty to assaulting a man after an altercation outside a pub.
Grant was jailed for a total of 11 months. Here's the full court report.
Kristjan Kaza
An Albanian cannabis farmer entered the UK illegally for a second time after being deported and was arrested in County Durham.
Kristjan Kaza had first entered Britain illegally in 2022 and was deported two years later after receiving a 22 month prison sentence for production of cannabis. But the 29-year-old was caught in the country again just months later, this time in Stanley in February this year.
Kaza later admitted he'd entered the UK illegally for a second time on a lorry for the sole purpose of working in cannabis production. He said he had paid up to eight thousand euros to be smuggled back into the UK.
Kaza appeared at Durham Crown Court to be sentenced for entering the UK in breach of a deportation order. He was jailed for 22 months, which will be served consecutively to the remaining 20 months of the prison sentence he received for production of cannabis in 2024. Here's the full story.
Michael Swinhoe
A brave dad ran at a robber "like a charging rhino" after he threatened to kidnap and rape his children while trying to steal his car.
The dad was putting his children in the car to take them to school when drugged up Michael Swinhoe turned up threatening him with a large rock and demanding his "£100,000 car". After uttering the vile threats about the youngsters, the father courageously took the armed assailant to the ground.
Swinhoe pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and possessing an offensive weapon. He was jailed for three years and nine months. Read the full story here.
Craig Irving and Clark Morrison
A woman's life "flashed before her eyes" when she investigated a noise in her home and was confronted by a masked gunman.
The victim had been upstairs getting ready to go out for dinner with her partner when they heard a sound from the front door that they thought was a family member coming in. But Newcastle Crown Court heard when she got downstairs she was confronted by armed strangers Craig Irving and Clark Morrison, who were wearing balaclavas and carrying what she believed was a double barrel shotgun and a sword.
The terrifying two-minute confrontation came to a sudden end when the men were told that the person they were most likely looking for no longer lived at the house in Forest Hall, North Tyneside. They said that person they were after "owed a lot of people a lot of money" before they left in a getaway car.
Irving, 44, of Midway, Walker, Newcastle, admitted having an imitation firearm and was jailed for three years and 11 months. Morrison, 20, of McIlvenna Gardens, Wallsend, admitted having an imitation firearm and threatening another with a bladed article. He was jailed for two years and ten months. Here's the full court report.
Brian Rumley
Two men broke into an indoor market and stole a large garden gorilla ornament.
Brian Rumley and Michael O’Brien broke into Darlington Indoor Market on March 25 and stole the ornament, worth £399, from one of the stalls. They were spotted on CCTV, arrested and taken to police custody where they were later charged with burglary.
They both pleaded guilty to the offence. Rumley was jailed for 16 weeks while O’Brien was jailed for three months, suspended for a year. Here's the full story.
Daniel Holland
A "Jekyll and Hyde" dating app rapist who attacked two women he met online was branded a "monster" as he was jailed for more than 12 years.
Former Royal Navy harbour pilot Daniel Holland subjected two women to sickening and painful attacks and also violently attacked one of them. A court heard Holland also tried to communicate sexually with a 13-year-old child online.
The 39-year-old, formerly of Newcastle, was branded a danger by a judge as he was locked up. He pleaded guilty to two counts of rape and one of GBH. He was convicted of attempted sexual communication with a child. Read the full story here.
Brian Wardropper
A thug released from a life sentence "flipped" and strangled a woman while threatening to kill her.
Brian Wardropper was jailed for life in 1999 for offences of wounding with intent and child destruction. In April, the 51-year-old was back behind bars for a terrifying attack on a woman with whom he had been intimate.
Newcastle Crown Court heard the victim had known Wardropper for around five years because he previously lived next door to her aunt in Houghton-le-Spring. They developed a friendship which became intimate.
On April 6 last year, the woman ended up at his home when he turned violent. Wardropper, of Station Avenue South, Fencehouses, pleaded guilty to assault occasioning actual bodily harm and strangulation and was jailed for 18 months. Here's the full story.
Tony Hall
A prolific offender who carried out a series of attacks on taxis and other vehicles in Newcastle suburbs was jailed and banned from entering two areas of the city.
Tony Hall persistently targeted Tyneside taxi drivers, regularly smashing windows and stealing from their cars in Heaton, Jesmond, Fenham and the West End of Newcastle. Drivers and their employees were left with repair bills totalling thousands.
After an investigation involving Northumbria Police and Newcastle City Council's licensing department, Hall was slapped with a Criminal Behaviour Order. He will be prevented from entering Heaton and Jesmond for the next two years on his release from prison.
The order was granted at North Tyneside Magistrates' Court, alongside a 32-week jail sentence after the 36-year-old pleaded guilty to charges of theft, fraud, and possession of crack cocaine. Here's the full story.
Jack Oughton
A thug was jailed after assaulting a police officer and causing him to temporarily lose vision in one eye.
PC Josh Elliott, of Durham Constabulary, was checking out a stolen car in Tow Law's Co-Op car park when he came across the suspect driver in the street. Jack Oughton, 24, attacked the officer as he was being questioned; continuously punching, headbutting, kicking and attempting to choke PC Elliott.
PC Elliott pressed his emergency button and a member of the public helped to restrain Oughton as fellow officers came to his aid. He arrested Oughton, despite suffering a concussion, fractured nose, and losing vision in his left eye in the attack.
Oughton had also dropped a Stanley knife and cannisters of nitrous oxide which were recovered by officers. PC Elliott was taken to hospital for treatment and his eyesight has now returned.
Oughton pleaded guilty to assault causing actual bodily harm, driving with no licence or insurance, possession of a bladed article and possession of a Class C drug. He was sentenced to 36 weeks in prison, whilst also being recalled for a previous robbery for two years and three months. Here's the full story.
Curtis Cruickshank
A persistent predator who breached a court order to abuse a teenage girl around Newcastle city centre was jailed for 13 years.
Curtis Cruickshank, now 23, was handed a two-year Sexual Risk Order in April 2021 which prohibited him from having any unsupervised contact with children and using the internet to contact children. This was in response to a series of emerging and worrying behaviours exhibited by Cruickshank indicating he had a sexual interest in children.
However, in November 2022, he added a teenager on social media, pushing her to send illicit pictures and videos of herself to him. Cruickshank's offending soon intensified as he persuaded the girl to meet up with him in derelict spots of Newcastle city centre where he pressured her to have sex with him and perform sexual acts on him in public.
The teen disclosed what had happened to a family member who later informed police – and an investigation was launched. In August 2024, Cruickshank – who was already in prison for breaching his SRO in an unrelated offence – was charged with 19 offences, including engaging in penetrative sexual activity with a child, meeting a child following grooming, and breaching a Sexual Risk Order.
In November, he stood trial at Newcastle Crown Court where he pleaded guilty to all 19 offences. And in April, a judge sentenced him to 13 years and six months' imprisonment, with a further six years on extended licence once he is released. Here's the full story.
Kenneth Scott
A crooked accountant spent tens of thousands of pounds on luxury holidays and a flash car while cheating the taxman out of £1.7m.
Kenneth Scott operated seven financial services companies across the North East, with offices in Newcastle, South Shields, Hexham and County Durham. Newcastle Crown Court heard the firms' 27 employees had tax and national insurance deducted from their wages but the money was never passed on to the Inland Revenue.
Clients were charged VAT, despite the group not being registered, which was not handed over to the HMRC. The court heard during the seven year revenue dodge, Scott went on a series of lavish trips.
Scott, 69, of Fir Tree, Crook, County Durham, admitted two charges of cheating the revenue out of a total of £1.7m between April 2014 and March 2021. He was jailed for four years. Read the full story here.
Sam Clarke
A student who sexually assaulted a sleeping woman was jailed.
The victim woke to find drunken Sam Clarke was molesting her in a house after a party. A judge at Newcastle Crown Court said he "pretended to be confused" when the victim woke up and reacted to what he was doing.
He then claimed she had been awake and had consented to what he did, but he later apologised. Clarke, 23, of Grange Road, Fenham, Newcastle, was found guilty of assault by penetration and was jailed for four-and-a-half years. Here's the full story.
David Weatherson
Murdered Bradley Tams' cousin was jailed for threatening the father of a man cleared of killing Bradley with a broken bottle.
David Weatherson attended Newcastle Crown Court for a hearing in which Gavin Train admitted murdering Bradley but prosecutors dropped the allegation against Lewis Allison and accepted his plea to violent disorder. Weatherson, who was in an "emotional state" after the hearing, followed Allison's father, Christopher Allison, from the court building, picked up a bottle, struck him with it then tried to hit him twice more after it smashed, warning: "I'm going to do time for your murder."
In April, Weatherson, 37, of Haig Crescent, Scotswood, Newcastle, was locked up for 16 months by the same judge who presided over the murder hearing last June. Weatherson pleaded guilty to threatening with an article with a blade or point. Here's the full court report.
Alan Dugdale
A Good Samaritan was slashed and stabbed with a steak knife by a man whose life he saved in a "gruesome" attack.
The victim had previously come to the aid of Alan Dugdale after he overdosed outside his house in Byker, Newcastle. When Dugdale later turned up at the man's home with partner Jamie Burrows, he ended up agreeing to let them in, a court heard.
Jessica Slaughter, prosecuting, told Newcastle Crown Court the trio consumed alcohol and then there came a point where: "The couple suggested the three of them have sex together."
The victim agreed but as he engaged in a sex act with Burrows, Dugdale attacked him. Dugdale pleaded guilty to robbery and having a bladed article. The 51-year-old, of Laurel Street, Wallsend, also admitted assaulting police when they arrested him on another occasion.
Dugdale was jailed for a total of 12 years and four months. Here's the full story.
Glenn Armstrong
A jealous stalker who broke into his ex-partner's house and brandished a kitchen knife was jailed for five years.
Glenn Armstrong, 37, had been bombarding the woman with unwanted messages before he forced his way into her Spennymoor home. In the messages, he threatened to kill the woman and one of her friends, saying that he had access to "knives, guns, and dogs", adding: "20 years in jail don't bother me, I'll laugh cos you'll be dead haha."
When officers attended the scene, they found Armstrong at the top of the stairs with the large knife, and tasered him. He was arrested, and later charged with aggravated burglary and stalking involving fear and violence. Armstrong, of Spennymoor, pleaded guilty to both the charges and was jailed for five years and four months. Read the full story here.
Colin Pearson
Two men were seriously injured when a thug used a "highly dangerous" XL Bully dog as an attack weapon.
Colin Pearson was in control of the dog, called King, when he got into an altercation with Kurtis Rutter outside a shop. A court heard there was a brief fight between the men before Mr Rutter left the scene.
At that point Pearson let the dog off its lead with the instruction "get him" or "kill him". CCTV shows the horror of what happened next as King chased down Mr Rutter, took him to the ground and latched onto his neck for around a minute. Brave passer-by Jake Moan was then also mauled after stopping his car to try to come to the aid of Mr Rutter.
Pearson, 44, of Noble Street, Sunderland, pleaded guilty to two counts of being a person in charge of a dog dangerously out of control causing injury. He was also in breach of two suspended prison sentences and was jailed for a total of three years. Here's the full court report.
Connor Hicks, Cameron Williams, John Williams
Three family members who took part in far-right riots in Sunderland were locked up.
Council worker Connor Hicks, 20, Cameron Williams, 29, and John Williams, 32, all attended the protests in the city centre on August 2 last year, and became actively involved in the widespread disorder. All three were seen behaving aggressively towards officers, with brothers Cameron and John Williams throwing pint glasses at the police line.
Cameron Williams, of Ridley Street, Southwick, Sunderland, John Williams, of Tennyson Avenue, Boldon, and Connor Hicks, of Exeter Street, Pallion, Sunderland, appeared at Newcastle Crown Court to be sentenced for violent disorder. All three had pleaded guilty.
Hicks was sentenced to 25 months in a young offenders institution, John Williams was jailed for 25 months and Cameron Williams was jailed for 25 months. Here's the full story.
Lee Hetherington
A serial thief caused almost £6,000 of damage breaking into a school.
Lee Hetherington was already on bail and subject to a suspended prison sentence when he broke into Cardinal Hume Catholic School, in Gateshead, in January. CCTV showed him using a tool to break in and he then broke the glass in another door and caused further damage.
The 26-year-old, of Denmark Street, Gateshead, also burgled two business premises in Felling, Gateshead, in June last year. And he also twice stole three vacuum cleaners worth £207 on consecutive days in April last year from B&M, in Prudhoe.
He pleaded guilty to offences of burglary and theft and also admitted being in breach of a suspended prison sentence. He was jailed for a total of 26 months. Here's the full story.
Jeffrey Rose
A rape victim told her abuser how he made her feel like a "piece of meat" as he was jailed for vile crimes committed almost 50 years ago.
Jeffrey Rose, who escaped justice for almost half a century, was put behind bars thanks to the woman's bravery. Rose, now 75, targeted his victim in the late 1970s. However, she did not report what had happened to her until 2020.
He denied the allegations but following a trial at Newcastle Crown Court Rose was found guilty of 20 offences including rape, attempted rape and indecent assault. Rose, of Hazel Cottages, Otterburn, Northumberland, was jailed for 17 years. Read the full story here.
Amanda Moderate
A despicable niece was branded "wicked" for fleecing her elderly aunt out of more than £80,000.
Amanda Moderate betrayed the trust of the victim, who was in her 90s, by plundering her savings and spending them on herself. There had been frequent purchases for Moderate's benefit, including on jewellery, hairdressing, lottery tickets, mobile phones, items from Next and food from Wagamama and Papa Johns.
Moderate, 49, of Century House, North Shields, defrauded her aunt out of a total of £82,046. She pleaded guilty to fraud by abuse of position and was locked up for 28 months. Read the full court report here.
Charles Moore
A shop worker was confronted by an axe-wielding robber when she tried to stop him stealing fabric conditioner.
Charles Moore, who had stolen two bottles of Lenor from Boyes, in Blyth, went back the following day to steal more of it. The assistant manager was made aware by a customer of what he was up to and she challenged him.
Newcastle Crown Court heard he then turned around and brandished an axe he had also picked up in the shop, frightening the worker. He left with the stolen items but then returned a short time later and returned them.
Moore, 43, of Twentythird Avenue, Blyth, pleaded guilty to robbery, having a bladed article and theft, and was sentenced to 30 months in prison. Here's the full story.
Mark McCrory
A violent thug stabbed a man in the face during an argument.
The victim had been staying at a woman's house in Newcastle when she invited two men back in the early hours, including Mark McCrory. An argument blew up between the victim and McCrory which escalated into violence.
Newcastle Crown Court heard McCrory took a small folding knife and stabbed the man in the face, causing lacerations to his forehead and lip. The woman left the flat and called the police and when they got there, they found McCrory shirtless, aggressive and stood over the victim on the sofa.
McCrory was originally accused of wounding with intent but prosecutors accepted his guilty plea to unlawful wounding. He was jailed for 25 months. Here's the full report.
Bashir Zairi, Thomas Conlon, Sezgin Yilmaz, James Williams, Steven Bruce
Five men falsely imprisoned a man after travelling from London to Gateshead and raiding a suspected cannabis farm.
The men travelled to a property on Westbourne Avenue in October last year in an attempt to locate a man they believed was tending to a cannabis farm. On finding the man, they put him in a vehicle before emptying the farm of 50 cannabis plants and leaving the North East, with one of the vehicles having cloned plates and the other stolen.
Members of the public raised the alarm after noticing suspicious activity and officers began a pursuit to trace the group. Officers stopped a van containing three of the men on the M1 in South Yorkshire, while two others were arrested in London in the following weeks.
James Williams was charged with kidnapping, possession of cannabis with intent to supply, dangerous driving and driving with no insurance. Accomplices Sezgin Yilmaz, Bashir Zairi, Thomas Conlon and Steven Bruce were all charged with kidnapping and possession of cannabis with intent to supply.
All five were due to stand trial at Newcastle Crown Court. However, before the jury were sworn in, the prosecution accepted guilty pleas from all defendants to the charge of false imprisonment rather than kidnapping, while guilty pleas to the drugs charges were accepted.
Williams was sentenced to three years and two months in prison. Yilmaz and Zairi received sentences of two years and six months. Conlon and Bruce were both jailed for two years and four months for their part in the incident. Here's the full story.
Darren John Waugh
A thug with a history of violence fractured a fellow prisoner's skull while on remand at HMP Durham after being called a "nonce".
Darren John Waugh was on remand at the County Durham jail when he launched a surprise attack on another prisoner and rendered him unconscious. The victim was rushed to hospital where it was found he had a fractured skull and bruising to his brain.
Waugh appeared at Durham Crown Court to be sentenced for grievous bodily harm. He had pleaded guilty to the offence. The court heard Waugh was on remand at the time of the offence for a section 18 wounding offence, for which he was later given an extended prison sentence of nine years - six years of which was custodial.
He was handed a two-year prison sentence, which will be served consecutively to the one he is already serving. Read the full story here.
Michael Crozier
A serial thief who repeatedly targeted shops he was barred from was finally locked up.
Time and time again, Michael Crozier stole items from various stores in Blyth. A court heard 75 of his 116 previous convictions were for theft.
He was given a Criminal Behaviour Order in 2023 banning him from areas including Blyth town centre and Asda, Aldi, Lidl and the Co-op. The order also banned him from being intoxicated in public or having open alcohol containers in public.
In May last year, he was given a 20 month suspended sentence for breaching the Criminal Behaviour Order and more shop thefts. Despite having that hanging over his head, he went on another spree of offences in July, August and September, stealing items including alcohol, detergent on seven occasions, hair straighteners and coffee from stores including Asda, Farm Foods, Morrisons and B&M.
Crozier pleaded guilty to ten offences of shop theft and nine of breaching the Criminal Behaviour Order. A judge activated 14 months of his previous suspended sentence and jailed him for ten months for the new breaches and thefts, meaning he got a total of two years. Here's the full story.
Paul Hughes
A killer driver was back behind bars for subjecting his partner to a barrage of "mental torture".
Paul Hughes, jailed for causing death by careless driving in 2018, left his then-girlfriend so scared she had to move out of the area and away from her children to feel safe. As well as taking control of her life, he also abused her mentally and physically, Newcastle Crown Court heard.
The 39-year-old, of Simonburn Avenue, North Shields, pleaded guilty to controlling or coercive behaviour and assault occasioning actual bodily harm. He was jailed for 38 months. Read the full story here.
Mark King
A rioter who launched missiles and threw beer kegs at police during the Sunderland riot was jailed.
Mark King, 25, was caught on CCTV taking part in the widespread rioting in the city on August 2 last year. Footage showed King trying to conceal his identity as he approached the police line and began to throw missiles.
King, of Caithness Road, Hylton Castle, Sunderland, was then captured throwing beer kegs from the window of The Yard. Newcastle Crown Court heard King had become "wrapped up" in the violence when he was out with a friend.
King pleaded guilty to one count of riot and was jailed for three years and four months. Here's the full story.
Joseph Smith
A shoplifter killed a pensioner by shoving her out of the way as he fled a sports shop after stealing socks.
Joseph Smith was on drugs and looking for valuables when he helped himself to three packs of socks from Sports Direct and made a run for it after setting off store alarms. As he raced around a blind corner into a back alley, he came face to face with football fans Christine and Sidney Vasey.
The childhood sweethearts had travelled to watch a Sunderland match from their home in Doncaster and were in the city centre ahead of the game. Smith forcefully shoved 68-year-old Mrs Vasey out of his way, causing her to fall back and crack her head on the ground, leading to a devastating head injury from which she died a few days later.
Smith, 37, of Halstead Square, Sunderland, was jailed for six years for manslaughter. Here's the full court report.
Owen Trebell
A Darlington man was jailed after using a needle to threaten his victims into handing over a wallet and a bag.
Owen Trebell approached his first victim on the morning of January 2 at a bus stop on Northgate in Darlington. The 43-year-old brandished the needle and asked the victim for their wallet, but they refused and ran away.
A few moments later, Trebell targeted a second victim on Bondgate, grabbing her from behind and pulling her backpack by the straps. The victim turned around and grabbed her backpack from Trebell.
He then punched her in the face four times, before she fought back and managed to run away. Trebell pleaded guilty to two counts of attempted robbery and possession of a bladed/sharply pointed article in a public place. He was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison. Here's the full story.
Devon Critchlow
A 'creepy' predator followed a stranger walking alone at night then barged his way into her home and subjected her to a terrifying sex attack.
Devon Critchlow was out on the streets wearing black clothing with his hood up when he spotted the victim on her own, changed direction then tailed her through the darkness. Newcastle Crown Court heard when the woman got into her home, Critchlow pushed his way in and carried out a violent sex and strangulation attack that made her fear she would be raped and killed.
Prosecutors say it was only the woman's courage in fighting him off that brought the violence to an end. Critchlow, 21, of Rochester Close, North Seaton, Ashington, admitted assault, intentional strangulation and sexual assault. He also admitted committing an assault offence with intent to commit a sexual offence.
He was jailed for five years and three months with a five year extended licence. Read the full court report here.
Craig Bainbridge
A violent thug strangled his partner until she passed out in a hotel and emptied a cat litter tray over her head in "abhorrent" attacks.
Craig Bainbridge and his then-girlfriend had gone to Ramside Hall Hotel, in County Durham, and were in a room watching TV when Bainbridge became abusive. Newcastle Crown Court heard he punched her leg and called her names and she became upset and said she wanted to go home.
He said she was not going anywhere and sat on her, pinning her to the bed and pushed his thumbs into her windpipe until she passed out. When she came round, he was still on top of her and she punched him and managed to seek sanctuary in the bathroom.
Bainbridge, 37, pleaded guilty to strangulation, two assault charges and two counts of criminal damage. He was jailed for 25 months. Here's the full report.
Stevan Newton
A chemical attack at a pub left several customers in pain and distress with one man screaming: "My eyes, my eyes".
Stevan Newton squirted so much ammonia at three men in the toilet area of a North Tyneside pub, there was a puddle of it on the floor and a number of people were left with sore eyes and being or feeling sick. Newcastle Crown Court heard one victim suffered burns to his eyes and cheek.
When Newton, of Ensin Street, Walker, Newcastle, was arrested, he had 6.8g of cocaine and 1.8 kilos of cannabis but prosecutors accepted his pleas to simply possessing the drugs. He also admitted applying a corrosive fluid with intent and was jailed for 54 months with an extended licence period of a further 30 months. Read the full story here.
Carl Kelly
A man was jailed after admitting robbing a 75-year-old woman of her handbag in the street.
The victim had just got off the bus in Front Street, Chester-le-Street, when her bag was grabbed from behind. She tried to hold on to it but was dragged to the ground by Carl Kelly who managed to snatch the bag and flee the scene.
Kelly used the victim’s bank card to buy cigarettes and put credit on his pay point card. The 75-year-old victim sustained minor injuries but managed to go to a nearby shop to get help.
At the time of the incident, Kelly was on bail for several other offences from December last year. He pleaded guilty to robbery, attempted burglary, possession of a bladed article and a pointed article, assault on an emergency worker, shop theft and three charges of vehicle interference. He was jailed for three years and six months. Here's the full story.
Gary Brown, Mark Robson
Robbers got more than they bargained for when brave shop workers fought back and got the better of them.
Gary Brown held a knife towards the throat of one worker while Mark Robson helped himself to takings at a family-run store in South Tyneside. But after initially fleeing outside, the two victims courageously decided to defend their property.
Newcastle Crown Court heard they got the better of the raiders, one of whom ended up "rolled in a ball" on the ground. Robson, 43, of Beach Road, South Shields, and Brown, 38, of Beach Road, South Shields, both admitted robbery and Brown also admitted possessing a bladed article. Robson admitted robbery on the basis he didn't have a knife and offered no violence. Both were jailed for three years. Here's the full court report.
Aaron Hinsley
Aaron Hinsley repeatedly stabbed his former partner's friend after finding him hiding in her wardrobe.
The jealous thug had warned his ex he would do harm to any new man in her life and started stalking her. On his birthday last October, Hinsley forced entry to her home in Blyth, Northumberland, while her male friend was present.
The woman told the man to hide in her wardrobe but when Hinsley opened the door and found him, he pulled out a knife and stabbed him. The 27-year-old, of Ingram Drive, Blyth, was jailed for five years and nine months for wounding with intent, aggravated burglary and stalking. Here's the full story.
Ryan Black
A domestic abuser strangled his girlfriend and "set fire to her hair" during a violent relationship.
Ryan Black left his now ex-partner unconscious after he strangled her in one incident, humiliated her by calling her derogatory names and "slammed her" to the ground. The 40-year-old also regularly controlled her finances and accused her of cheating on him.
Newcastle Crown Court heard that Black strangled her on more than one occasion and threatened to kill her and members of her family by setting a house on fire. The court heard his violent behaviour usually surfaced when he had been drinking alcohol.
Black, of Farne Terrace, Walker, Newcastle, appeared at the court to be sentenced for controlling or coercive behaviour and two counts of intentional strangulation. He was found guilty after a trial and was jailed for four years and four months. Read the full court report here.
Bailey Wood, Marc Robson
Two men terrorised a former soldier in his own flat and "toyed" with him during a violent and prolonged attack.
Marc Robson, 38, and Bailey Wood, 21, launched a vicious attack on a vulnerable man in his own flat in Swalwell, Gateshead, after they turned up to his home with two others. It wasn't long before the pair unleashed a sickening attack on the man that left him with a fractured eye socket and facial lacerations.
Newcastle Crown Court heard that the victim was repeatedly kicked, stamped on, hit with a crutch and choked during the ordeal. Robson also threatened to stab him with a shard of a plate after he had smashed it over his own head.
Robson and Wood appeared at the court to be sentenced for inflicting grievous bodily harm. They had both pleaded guilty. Robson was jailed for two years and three months and Wood was jailed for 21 months. Here's the full story.
Peter Dellbridge
A rapist forced a child to watch pornography during sickening sexual abuse.
Peter Dellbridge carried out the horrific sexual abuse and rape of a young child. The 64-year-old's grooming behaviour and abuse was said to have had a devastating impact on his vulnerable victim.
Newcastle Crown Court heard that Dellbridge's offending finally came to light when his victim confided in their partner and a therapist years after the abuse. Dellbridge appeared at the court to be sentenced for offences of causing a child to watch sexual activity, sexual assault of a child, assault by penetration, inciting a child to engage in sexual activity and two counts of rape.
Dellbridge, of Seaton Delaval, North Tyneside, was found guilty of the offences following a trial. He was jailed for 16 years. Here's the full story.
Brandon Bushby
A man was jailed after he brandished a knife at a group of men in a busy town centre.
Brandon Bushby had been released from prison for a knife offence and was on licence when he was caught brandishing a knife in South Shields town centre. The 32-year-old had the knife in his possession while children and other members of the public were in the area.
CCTV operators captured the interaction and notified police, but Bushby fled in a Ford Fiesta, despite having no driving licence or insurance. He was caught days later and recalled to prison.
Bushby, of Dunholm Road, Newcastle, was sentenced for possession of a bladed article and driving with no licence or insurance. He had pleaded guilty. He was jailed for 16 months. Read the full story here.
Amy Elstob, Kevin Slack

Three people were jailed for their part in a sex trafficking ring between the UK and Romania.

A total of 16 people were sentenced as police tackled a County Lines operation that was bringing drugs such as cocaine and heroin into the region.
Northumbria Police has been spearheading the action to stop organised criminals shipping Class A drugs into the North East. They were jailed for over 60 years in total between them, with others given suspended prison sentences for their part in the operation.
The investigation, known as Operation Girona, uncovered that around five kilos of cocaine and heroin were distributed from the Cheshire and Merseyside areas between January 2018 and September 2020. The primary group from the North West, who initially set up the operation, relied upon a network of dealers in the North East, who generated around £500,000 through the illicit trading.
Of the 16 men in question, eight were based in the North East, and two of them were jailed. Brian Old, 52, of Wallace Gardens, Gateshead, pleaded guilty to being concern in supply of Class A drug, possession with intent to supply heroin, and acquire, use or possess criminal property, and was jailed for four years and one month.
Declan Williams, 24, of Thorpe Street, Easington, pleaded guilty to being concerned in the supply of Class A drug and was jailed for three years and two months. Here's the full story, which includes all the sentences.
